pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.html:
I get the following warning two times whenever I open gzserver --verbose:

[Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:209] Cannot set physics engine type from GetParam.

We should remove the warning console message and document that type can't currently be set with SetParam (not GetParam). We can still return false, so the users will have some idea that it didn't work.

diff -r 159abc5ede7a gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc   Fri Mar 27 15:19:20 2015 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.cc   Fri Mar 27 15:38:46 2015 -0700
@@ -206,7 +206,7 @@
   {
     if (_key == "type")
     {
-      gzwarn << "Cannot set physics engine type from GetParam." << std::endl;
+      // Cannot set physics engine type from SetParam
       return false;
     }
     if (_key == "max_step_size")

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.html:
When I deleted "GetAnySDFValue" in the last commit, I got rid of a conversion from sdf::Vector3 to math::Vector3:

else if (typeid(sdf::Vector3) == _elem->GetValue()->GetType())
{
   ret = _elem->Get<gazebo::math::Vector3>();
}

I believe Element::Get is able to convert the SDF::Vector3 object to a math::Vector3 because of the lexical_cast done in Param.hh of SDF.

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw:
I wanted to check if sending a physics message with both a profile name and another physics parameter set would cause the message parameter to override the profile parameter, which I think it should. For example, `preset_1` in [test/worlds/presets.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/test/worlds/presets.world) has a max time step of `0.01`.
~~~
$ gz physics -s 0.001
# should set the time step to 0.001
$ gz physics -p preset_1
# should set the time step to 0.01
# but calling both:
$ gz physics -p preset_1 -s 0.001
# should defer to the parameter set explicitly by the user
# and set the time step to 0.001
~~~
I added a test for this in 4d43d3c (branch `physics_presets_cli_scpeters`) and fixed the test in a47edc1. It's a pretty small change, so please consider merging it in.
content.html:
I wanted to check if sending a physics message with both a profile name and another physics parameter set would cause the message parameter to override the profile parameter, which I think it should. For example, preset_1 in test/worlds/presets.world has a max time step of 0.01.

$ gz physics -s 0.001
# should set the time step to 0.001
$ gz physics -p preset_1
# should set the time step to 0.01
# but calling both:
$ gz physics -p preset_1 -s 0.001
# should defer to the parameter set explicitly by the user
# and set the time step to 0.001

I added a test for this in 4d43d3c (branch physics_presets_cli_scpeters) and fixed the test in a47edc1. It's a pretty small change, so please consider merging it in.

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw:
I'm conflicted about adding a warning here, it may lead to spurious messages.

This check is here because there are some elements that have multiple blocks for each physics engine (see [`test/worlds/presets.world`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d7da929b192d3e7e1ddcd3cd49c2f67d07de8d9d/test/worlds/presets.world?at=default)). This check ignores a block that is named for a different physics engine than the one that was assigned at runtime. In the example I linked, `ode` is the default physics type, so this line skips over the blocks `simbody` and `bullet` so that the physics engine doesn't try to add a lot of parameters that will give warnings. Therefore, if I add a warning here, it will be displayed 3 times whenever this world gets loaded.
content.html:
I'm conflicted about adding a warning here, it may lead to spurious messages.

This check is here because there are some elements that have multiple blocks for each physics engine (see test/worlds/presets.world). This check ignores a block that is named for a different physics engine than the one that was assigned at runtime. In the example I linked, ode is the default physics type, so this line skips over the blocks simbody and bullet so that the physics engine doesn't try to add a lot of parameters that will give warnings. Therefore, if I add a warning here, it will be displayed 3 times whenever this world gets loaded.

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: Since this is the end condition of recursion, we are expected to reach this statement when we reach past the leaves of the SDF element tree (it would be bad if we didn't because the function would go on forever). There is an assert in `GenerateSDFFromPreset` before `GenerateSDFHelper` is called the check that the root SDF element is not NULL.
content.html: Since this is the end condition of recursion, we are expected to reach this statement when we reach past the leaves of the SDF element tree (it would be bad if we didn't because the function would go on forever). There is an assert in GenerateSDFFromPreset before GenerateSDFHelper is called the check that the root SDF element is not NULL.

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: Agreed it would be nice to fix, but it might require major changes. The GUI currently receives physics parameters via a [physics_info request/response](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6c6e3d6048edca82d6fce6aaff65c59b4b98bcc/gazebo/gui/ModelListWidget.cc#cl-184). This would probably need to be changed to publish/subscribe? Or maybe the GUI needs to listen to the `~/physics` topic, and whenever a message is published there (that wasn't published by the gui itself), it could trigger a new `physics_info` request?
content.html: Agreed it would be nice to fix, but it might require major changes. The GUI currently receives physics parameters via a physics_info request/response. This would probably need to be changed to publish/subscribe? Or maybe the GUI needs to listen to the ~/physics topic, and whenever a message is published there (that wasn't published by the gui itself), it could trigger a new physics_info request?

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: Indeed, I think it's a problem with the pipeline between physics engine updates and the GUI that we didn't really notice until now, and not specific to this PR... If you use `gz physics --iters` to change the number of iterations, the behavior is the same. Ticketed as #1558
content.html: Indeed, I think it's a problem with the pipeline between physics engine updates and the GUI that we didn't really notice until now, and not specific to this PR... If you use gz physics --iters to change the number of iterations, the behavior is the same. Ticketed as #1558

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: I made some in tweaks in e943518 to improve branch coverage and caught some mistakes, dead code, etc. In particular, I decided to get rid of `Preset::Name(const std::string&` because I realized that it's a bad idea to change the name of a preset without changing its SDF or its key in the `PresetManager` storage. I also made `PresetManager::ProfileSDF(Preset, sdf::ElementPtr)` return a bool and added more error checking, and changed some internal checks to GZ_ASSERTS.
content.html: I made some in tweaks in e943518 to improve branch coverage and caught some mistakes, dead code, etc. In particular, I decided to get rid of Preset::Name(const std::string& because I realized that it's a bad idea to change the name of a preset without changing its SDF or its key in the PresetManager storage. I also made PresetManager::ProfileSDF(Preset, sdf::ElementPtr) return a bool and added more error checking, and changed some internal checks to GZ_ASSERTS.

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: Is there a way of running the coverage report on my machine and only one class/set of tests, or do I need to run it on Jenkins?
content.html: Is there a way of running the coverage report on my machine and only one class/set of tests, or do I need to run it on Jenkins?

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw:
Here are some [instructions](http://internal.osrfoundation.org/ManualCodeCoverageInspection?highlight=%28bullseye%29).

You can also install `lcov`, and then:

1. `cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage ../`
1. `make`
1. Run your test
1. `make coverage`
1. `firefox build/coverage/index.html`
content.html:
Here are some instructions.

You can also install lcov, and then:

  1. cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Coverage ../
  2. make
  3. Run your test
  4. make coverage
  5. firefox build/coverage/index.html

pullrequest.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

content.raw: Potential race condition here. I think `PresetManager` class is not threadsafe and we're not using any mutex here either. Probably it's easier to add a mutex in `PresetManager` for protecting at least `this->dataPtr->currentProfile`.
content.html: Potential race condition here. I think PresetManager class is not threadsafe and we're not using any mutex here either. Probably it's easier to add a mutex in PresetManager for protecting at least this->dataPtr->currentProfile.
